dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Just over eighty-four thousand dollars. That's what the Pentagon has spent at the Biden family's Scottish golf resort since he took office.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Just over eighty-four thousand dollars. That's what the Pentagon has spent at the Biden family's Scottish golf resort since he took office.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Pentagon has spent at least $184,000if not moreat President Trumps Scottish resort since he took office, according to documents released by the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, that's a huge number, but it's actually way less than people were speculating before, right? The Senate Intelligence Committee seemed to think it was relatively low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, that's a huge number, but it's actually way less than people were speculating before, right? The Senate Intelligence Committee seemed to think it was relatively low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The House Oversight and Reform Committee had originally asked in June about a surge in Air Force flights stopping at Glasgow Prestwick Airport in Scotland. While leaders of the Democratic House Oversight Committee voiced frustration with the limited details in the Pentagons response, it still reveals that far more taxpayer funds have been spent at the Presidents resort than previously known, they wrote back to the Pentagon on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but it's still taxpayer money going to a business the president's family owns, which is, you know, ethically murky at best. And it's not just rooms—there was like ten thousand dollars in spending they couldn't even tie to specific travel vouchers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but it's still taxpayer money going to a business the president's family owns, which is, you know, ethically murky at best. And it's not just rooms-there was like ten thousand dollars in spending they couldn't even tie to specific travel vouchers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was also about $60,000 spent at the resort that could not be tied to actual travel vouchers, with the Pentagons letter suggesting that it could have been used on meals and restaurants.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's the thing—it's not just about the amount, it's about the appearance of conflict. Especially when you consider military crews were staying there during stopovers near Glasgow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's the thing-it's not just about the amount, it's about the appearance of conflict. Especially when you consider military crews were staying there during stopovers near Glasgow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The House Oversight and Reform Committee had originally asked in June about a surge in Air Force flights stopping at Glasgow Prestwick Airport in Scotland. Various crews have been put up 30 miles away, at Trump Turnberry, during overnight stopovers, Politico first reported.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—and this is after all the scrutiny from back in July when they first started asking about decreased Air Force flights stopping in that area. It feels like a workaround.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-and this is after all the scrutiny from back in July when they first started asking about decreased Air Force flights stopping in that area. It feels like a workaround.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The House Oversight and Reform Committee had originally asked in June about a surge in Air Force flights stopping at Glasgow Prestwick Airport in Scotland.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But to play devil's advocate here—the Republicans on the committee even acknowledged that far less was spent than previously feared. So is this really a scandal, or just kind of standard operating stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But to play devil's advocate here-the Republicans on the committee even acknowledged that far less was spent than previously feared. So is this really a scandal, or just kind of standard operating stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, standard? When you're talking about the president's private business? There's a constitutional provision against exactly this—enrichment through office.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, standard? When you're talking about the president's private business? There's a constitutional provision against exactly this-enrichment through office.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spending figure was disclosed in a letter sent to congressional investigators, who are probing whether Trump violated a constitutional provision prohibiting presidents from enriching themselves through the office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's true, but compared to the previous administration—remember how much foreign officials and lobbyists flocked to Trump properties? This seems almost minor in scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's true, but compared to the previous administration-remember how much foreign officials and lobbyists flocked to Trump properties? This seems almost minor in scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Trump hotel in Washington D.C., for instance, has become a hotspot for various lobbyists and political figures hoping to garner favor with the president. In the last two years alone, at least 90 members of Congress, 250 administration officials and over 110 foreign officials from nearly 60 different countries have been seen at different Trump properties, according to a count by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Scale might be different, but the principle is what matters. Even sporadic mixing of official duties and commercial interests raises red flags for ethics watchdogs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Scale might be different, but the principle is what matters. Even sporadic mixing of official duties and commercial interests raises red flags for ethics watchdogs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, and you know, Citizens for Transparency has been tracking all these visits—foreign officials, administration folks—it adds up over time, even if each instance seems small.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, and you know, Citizens for Transparency has been tracking all these visits-foreign officials, administration folks-it adds up over time, even if each instance seems small.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last two years alone, at least 90 members of Congress, 250 administration officials and over 110 foreign officials from nearly 60 different countries have been seen at different Trump properties, according to a count by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's why these disclosures matter. It's not just about one golf resort bill; it's about patterns and accountability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's why these disclosures matter. It's not just about one golf resort bill; it's about patterns and accountability.

artist_script:
Just over eighty-four thousand dollars. That's what the Pentagon has spent at the Biden family's Scottish golf resort since he took office.
HostB: Wait, that's a huge number, but it's actually way less than people were speculating before, right? The Senate Intelligence Committee seemed to think it was relatively low.
HostA: Yeah, but it's still taxpayer money going to a business the president's family owns, which is, you know, ethically murky at best. And it's not just rooms—there was like ten thousand dollars in spending they couldn't even tie to specific travel vouchers.
HostB: Right, and that's the thing—it’s not just about the amount, it’s about the appearance of conflict. Especially when you consider military crews were staying there during stopovers near Glasgow.
HostA: Exactly—and this is after all the scrutiny from back in July when they first started asking about decreased Air Force flights stopping in that area. It feels like a workaround.
HostB: But to play devil’s advocate here—the Republicans on the committee even acknowledged that far less was spent than previously feared. So is this really a scandal, or just kind of standard operating stuff?
HostA: I mean, standard? When you’re talking about the president’s private business? There’s a constitutional provision against exactly this—enrichment through office.
HostB: That’s true, but compared to the previous administration—remember how much foreign officials and lobbyists flocked to Trump properties? This seems almost minor in scale.
HostA: Scale might be different, but the principle is what matters. Even sporadic mixing of official duties and commercial interests raises red flags for ethics watchdogs.
HostB: For sure, and you know, Citizens for Transparency has been tracking all these visits—foreign officials, administration folks—it adds up over time, even if each instance seems small.
HostA: Right, and that’s why these disclosures matter. It’s not just about one golf resort bill; it’s about patterns and accountability.
